â€œâ€¦In joining his fellow Texan Representative Jeb Hensarling in trying to block the reauthorization of the Ex-Im Bank, Cruz landed on the perfect vehicle to drive his charge against â€œcrony capitalism.â€ The Ex-Im Bank is a government agency established in 1934 to help facilitate U.S. exports. Congressional reauthorization of the organization was not controversial. In other words, it was a blank canvas on which Cruz and Hensarling could paint what they liked.

â€œIn launching his opposition, Cruz admitted as much, saying in an op-ed in USA Today, â€œTo most Americans, the words â€œExport-Import Bank donâ€™t mean very much.â€ He then fired a lopsided barrage against the bank, describing it as â€œbig businessesâ€™ big government bank backed by U.S. taxpayers.â€ He cites numerous examples of the bank financing projects in countries with unfriendly or corrupt regimes, such as China and Congo, and describing its practices as â€œmarkedly irresponsible.â€

Some of Cruzâ€™ criticisms are accurate. There have been charges of corruption, and like most federal institutions, the bank is not well run. However, for all the shortcomings, Ex-Im has operated since its founding with a default rate of 1 percent and, nearly alone among government agencies, the bank turns a profit. It contributed $674 million to taxpayers in 2014 and $432 million in 2015.

â€œMore important, the bank provides loans and loan guarantees to entities wishing to buy U.S.-made goods that otherwise would not be able to access credit to do so. That is why operations in places like Sudan and Russia are on the list.
